stem: A 45-year-old client is 12 hours post-operative following an open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) of a right tibial fracture sustained in a motor vehicle collision. The client has a splint and dressing applied to the right lower leg. The nurse is reviewing the client's electronic health record.
prompt: The nurse analyzes the trends in the client's assessment data. For each finding below, click to specify if it is consistent or not consistent with the development of acute compartment syndrome.

tabs.name: Assessment Flowsheet
rows: Able to wiggle toes, full ROM
Able to wiggle toes, full ROM
Reports tingling on top of foot
Cool, pale, very tense and shiny

rows.text: Increasing pain unrelieved by opioid analgesia
Worsening paresthesia in the affected extremity
Pain with passive extension of the toes
Presence of a palpable dorsalis pedis pulse
Progressive motor weakness in the foot
Tense and shiny appearance of the skin

row_1.rationale: This finding is consistent. Pain that is disproportionate to the injury and unrelieved by standard analgesia (especially opioids) is the cardinal and earliest sign of acute compartment syndrome. It is caused by muscle ischemia and nerve compression from rising pressure within the fascial compartment.

row_2.rationale: This finding is consistent. The trend from 'Intact' sensation to 'tingling' (paresthesia) and then 'numbness' indicates progressive nerve compression and ischemia. This is a key early neurological sign of compartment syndrome.

row_3.rationale: This finding is consistent. Pain on passive stretch of the muscles within the affected compartment is a classic and reliable early sign of compartment syndrome. For the anterior tibial compartment, this is elicited by passive plantar flexion; for the posterior compartment, by dorsiflexion/extension. This pain is due to ischemic muscle stretch.

row_4.rationale: This finding is not consistent. The presence of a distal pulse is an unreliable indicator and does not rule out compartment syndrome. Arterial pressure is typically much higher than the pressure within the compartment, so pulses can remain palpable until very late stages when irreversible damage has already occurred. The absence of a pulse (pulselessness) is a very late and ominous sign.

row_5.rationale: This finding is consistent. The trend shows a decline from full range of motion to weakness with dorsiflexion and finally to inability to move toes (paralysis). This progressive motor deficit is a sign of increasing nerve compression and muscle ischemia, indicating worsening compartment syndrome.

row_6.rationale: This finding is consistent. As fluid accumulates and pressure builds within the enclosed fascial compartment, the overlying skin becomes tense, cool, pale, and may appear shiny. The trend from 'moderate edema' to 'tense' and 'very tense and shiny' reflects this progression.

references.source: Ignatavicius, D. D., Workman, M. L., Rebar, C. R., & Heimgartner, N. M. (2021). Medical-surgical nursing: Concepts for interprofessional collaborative care (10th ed.). Elsevier.
references.chapter: Chapter on care of patients with musculoskeletal trauma.

references.source: Harding, M. M., Kwong, J., Roberts, D., Hagler, D., & Reinisch, C. (2020). Lewis's medical-surgical nursing: Assessment and management of clinical problems (11th ed.). Elsevier.
